content: @takenstheorem Giving appreciated crypto is a great idea. But you only get a deduction up to 30% of adjusted gross income. To pay zero federal taxes, donate 30% as crypto and 70% as US dollars (and talk to your accountant).
renderedContent: @takenstheorem Giving appreciated crypto is a great idea. But you only get a deduction up to 30% of adjusted gross income. To pay zero federal taxes, donate 30% as crypto and 70% as US dollars (and talk to your accountant).

content: Oh, and if you don’t already have a favorite charity, I’d suggest looking at the https://t.co/xE2J0pqWDQ recommendations for great places to give.
renderedContent: Oh, and if you don’t already have a favorite charity, I’d suggest looking at the givewell.org recommendations for great places to give.

content: If you’re planning on eventually donating a chunk of your wealth, this is a good year to do it; next year the charitable deduction rules revert back. Talk to your accountant.

content: Overall, nice experience. As always, don’t put your life savings into any bleeding-edge tech unless you can afford to lose it. And nobody is paying me to play with the shiny new layer2 toys.
renderedContent: Overall, nice experience. As always, don’t put your life savings into any bleeding-edge tech unless you can afford to lose it. And nobody is paying me to play with the shiny new layer2 toys.

content: I had a couple of mysterious Failed Transaction errors for L2 transactions, but trying again (as the UI suggested) worked.
renderedContent: I had a couple of mysterious Failed Transaction errors for L2 transactions, but trying again (as the UI suggested) worked.

content: Swaps and sends were wicked fast and cheap. Layer2 back to ETH main chain is $5 and takes maybe 30 minutes.
renderedContent: Swaps and sends were wicked fast and cheap. Layer2 back to ETH main chain is $5 and takes maybe 30 minutes.

content: UI was good— just a website connected to my metamask wallet.
renderedContent: UI was good— just a website connected to my metamask wallet.

content: Gas cost to deposit ETH was reasonable. Depositing ERC20 tokens was more expensive ($70 to approve then deposit at today’s gas price).
renderedContent: Gas cost to deposit ETH was reasonable. Depositing ERC20 tokens was more expensive ($70 to approve then deposit at today’s gas price).

content: I love the 50-free layer2-to-layer2 sends per day feature (and hope they manage to keep it).

quotedTweet.content:
Cairo proofs on Ropsten

Off-chain:
1. Write any foo(bar) in Cairo.
2. Compute foo(bar). Result=blah.
3. Compute STARK proof (@ https://t.co/NpxAkM0zzb; API soon).

On Ropsten:
4. If proof valid, store Fact “foo(bar)=blah” in Fact Registry.
5. Query Fact Registry from your dApp. https://t.co/mT0K9lBWpE
quotedTweet.renderedContent:
Cairo proofs on Ropsten

Off-chain:
1. Write any foo(bar) in Cairo.
2. Compute foo(bar). Result=blah.
3. Compute STARK proof (@ cairo-lang.org/playground; API soon).

On Ropsten:
4. If proof valid, store Fact “foo(bar)=blah” in Fact Registry.
5. Query Fact Registry from your dApp. https://t.co/mT0K9lBWpE

content: @jcansdale @JaEsf @PolymarketHQ So it only makes sense if you need the money to invest in something else (and think you’ll make more in that something else than you lose by closing your position).
renderedContent: @jcansdale @JaEsf @PolymarketHQ So it only makes sense if you need the money to invest in something else (and think you’ll make more in that something else than you lose by closing your position).

content:
@jcansdale @JaEsf @PolymarketHQ If you have 11 “yes” shares in a market, you can buy 11 “no” shares and the system will notice and zero out your share balance.

I’m also fuzzy on how that lets you avoid transaction fees (I guess you pay 2% after markets are resolved?)
renderedContent:
@jcansdale @JaEsf @PolymarketHQ If you have 11 “yes” shares in a market, you can buy 11 “no” shares and the system will notice and zero out your share balance.

I’m also fuzzy on how that lets you avoid transaction fees (I guess you pay 2% after markets are resolved?)

content: (Thanks to @PolymarketHQ for enlightening me)
renderedContent: (Thanks to @PolymarketHQ for enlightening me)

content: It’s a side effect of trading fees: “given there’s a 2% fee on trades, savvy traders have figured out it’s cheaper to buy the unlikely side to exit your large position rather than just selling your large position”
renderedContent: It’s a side effect of trading fees: “given there’s a 2% fee on trades, savvy traders have figured out it’s cheaper to buy the unlikely side to exit your large position rather than just selling your large position”

content: There are vaccines being developed (or that could be developed) to suit all of those irrational preferences. Don’t like needles? Take this nasal spray. Don’t like Big Pharma? Screw them! Take the open source vaccine from Harvard scientists!

content: @ZacharyCohn @dakami Maybe there is less bias if nobody can appeal. Maybe not. If you’re certain you know the answer, then I think you’re overconfident.
renderedContent: @ZacharyCohn @dakami Maybe there is less bias if nobody can appeal. Maybe not. If you’re certain you know the answer, then I think you’re overconfident.

content: @ZacharyCohn @dakami Maybe. I haven’t looked at how many signatures are rejected, how many rejections appealed, how many appeals are successful. Bias could happen at all of those stages.
renderedContent: @ZacharyCohn @dakami Maybe. I haven’t looked at how many signatures are rejected, how many rejections appealed, how many appeals are successful. Bias could happen at all of those stages.

content: @ZacharyCohn @dakami The ruling says voters can’t appeal any more; I bet there is bias in the existing system because less privileged voters are less likely to take the time to appeal. Anyway, maybe some clever polysci grad student can untangle the effects.
renderedContent: @ZacharyCohn @dakami The ruling says voters can’t appeal any more; I bet there is bias in the existing system because less privileged voters are less likely to take the time to appeal. Anyway, maybe some clever polysci grad student can untangle the effects.

content: @ZacharyCohn @dakami Are the town or county clerks who check signatures biased towards one party or another? Again, I’d bet it evens out and has close to zero effect on election outcome (but I might be wrong).
renderedContent: @ZacharyCohn @dakami Are the town or county clerks who check signatures biased towards one party or another? Again, I’d bet it evens out and has close to zero effect on election outcome (but I might be wrong).

content: @dakami “Meh” — I bet inconsistent signatures are randomly distributed among voters, so it won’t affect election results. I might be wrong; maybe suburban women all have perfect signatures (and tend to vote Democrat) or something.
renderedContent: @dakami “Meh” — I bet inconsistent signatures are randomly distributed among voters, so it won’t affect election results. I might be wrong; maybe suburban women all have perfect signatures (and tend to vote Democrat) or something.
